We provide a categorical definition of quantum theory. The definition is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. It is based on a small number of axioms that are satisfied by the category of Hilbert spaces and linear operators on them. The definition is intended to be a foundation for the mathematical theory of quantum theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of animals. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present a genomic and transcriptomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results support a sister relationship between the Myxozoa and cnidarians and suggest that the extreme reduction in the genome and gene content of the Myxozoa was accompanied by a reduction in the complexity of the body plan. These results provide insights into the origin of the Myxozoa and the evolution of the Myxozoan body plan. (PsycINFO Database Record

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and propagate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). Our results demonstrate that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the proton channel. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits the channel will further our understanding of the channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for the channel. The world’s food production will need to increase by 70% by 2050 to meet the needs of a projected 9 billion people. This increase will be challenging to achieve because of the increasing frequency of extreme weather events, including heat waves. Here, we show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase almost everywhere in the world, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase substantially in the top four maize-exporting countries. These results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is critical to understanding the mechanisms of coexistence in natural communities. However, the extent to which species differ in their diets is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. Our results suggest that the use of coarse trophic categories may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammalian herbivore communities. Our findings highlight the importance of species-level identification in studies of diet partitioning, and suggest that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

We provide evidence on the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on small businesses. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed. Many businesses are financially fragile, and many anticipate problems accessing government funding.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the magnitude and the fate of this pollution are still open questions. We show that the plastic debris is mostly accumulating in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres, but the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered.

The ability to increase the energy available to the mother is a key component of the evolution of all forms of care. Here, we show that the evolution of care is associated with an increase in reproductive output. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is associated with an increase in the size of the litter. This increase in litter size is associated with an increase in the energy available to the mother. This increase in energy is associated with an increase in the reproductive output of the mother.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to reduce the load of α-syn in oligodendrocytes and to protect neurons in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising drug for the treatment of MSA. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept for the potential of VX-765 to slow down the progression of MSA. The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. It is the primary regulator of vascular function and is the target of many diseases. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to control vascular function in a variety of ways. This paper describes the structure of the endothelium and the communication network between cells. The findings reveal that the endothelium is a highly connected network that is able to rapidly and efficiently integrate information from multiple sources. This structure is important for the control of vascular function.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. This paper describes the COVIDcast API, a data platform that provides open access to a wide range of data on the COVID-19 pandemic, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. The data are available for free to the public, and we encourage researchers to use and share the data.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This study shows that the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels is crucial for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. Interestingly, all of the mutant channels exhibited lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of their allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). A state-dependent crystallographic study of KcsA-T75A proves that, on activation, the selectivity filter transitions from a nonconductive and deep C-type inactivated conformation to a conductive one. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This study provides a deeper understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the gating of potassium channels. It also provides a new paradigm for the design of potassium channel modulators.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a dynamic community that is influenced by the host and the environment. The role of the microbiome in the health of the host is not fully understood, but it is clear that the composition of the microbiome is important for the health of the host. This study provides evidence that anaerobic fungi, which are members of the gut microbiome of herbivores, synthesize natural products that could be used as therapeutics.

The development of programmable materials and structures is of great importance for the design of multifunctional devices. However, the current approaches are limited by the use of a single material phase and the design of specific structural patterns. Here, we propose a synthesis method that can realize the programmable responses of materials and structures with multiple material phases. The proposed method can be extended to the design of multifunctional devices with complex behaviors. The developed programmable materials and structures can be used in a wide range of applications, such as soft robotics, soft robotics, and soft robotics. This work will provide a new paradigm for the design of programmable materials and structures.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development and differentiation in the human body. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in the human fetus and is down-regulated in the adult. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 is a key regulator of the timing of hemoglobin expression in the human body.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide. Despite recent advances in cancer treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to therapy and succumb to the disease. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids. This resistance is mediated by the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In addition, we found that SREBP1 mediates ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells through the transcriptional activation of stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), a key enzyme in the production of monounsaturated fatty acids. Thus, our findings suggest that targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway in combination with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for the treatment of cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells, which is mediated by the N terminus of the Ca2+ sensor protein STIM. Our findings suggest that the use of LCCBs should be limited in patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of LCCBs in the development of heart failure and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of hypertension. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations associated with early-seral forests but failed to reverse the decline of older-forest–associated species. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and the need to ensure that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Our study provides a proof of concept for the rational design of new antibiotics. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, and the network architecture is often complex, making it difficult to implement, train, and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is a classic example of the impact of environmental change on biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We show that the evolution of the species flock is linked to the evolution of the climate system, and that the lake underwent large-scale changes in hydroclimate and lake level over the last 1.3 My.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that the use of an electronic device in the hours before bedtime, such as an e-reader, can have a negative impact on sleep. This is the first study to show that the use of an e-reader in the hours before bedtime can have a negative impact on sleep.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) boundary is a key event in the history of the Earth system, and it is widely accepted that a bolide impact triggered the YDB. However, the origin of the impactor is still controversial. Here, we show that the osmium isotopic composition of the YDB is consistent with the terrestrial origin of the impactor.

The role of the negative regulator of T cell activation, cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4), in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 expression in adult mice results in a spectrum of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. This suggests that the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is dependent on the timing of its expression.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolution of beetles, including the impact of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remains poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the evolution of beetles, including the timing and rates of beetle diversification, the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls, and the evolution of beetle diversity. Our results suggest that beetles diversified in response to the evolution of genes encoding enzymes that enable efficient digestion of plant cell walls, including lignocellulose, and that this resulted in multiple adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles.

The development of new antiviral and vaccine strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic is urgently needed. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to enhance the neutralizing activity of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that can improve the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can potentially contribute to the development of new antiviral and vaccine strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of human culture and the design of social systems.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and is the sixth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is thought to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much more likely than that of the hcp phase, which is the stable phase of iron at the core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which is a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. Our results provide a new perspective on the formation of the inner core and its anisotropy. They also suggest that the core of the Moon, which is a solid core with a similar composition to that of the Earth's inner core, may have formed by a similar mechanism.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that the brain’s response to the stimulation of dopamine (DA) is blunted in marijuana abusers, which might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. These findings are important for understanding the brain mechanisms of addiction and for developing effective treatments for marijuana abuse.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the human brain is uniquely adapted to process language. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks also capture the brain’s language representations. This suggests that language processing in the human brain is fundamentally a predictive process. We discuss the implications of these results for the nature and organization of language in the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it is often unstable and slow to train. We show that this instability is due to the fact that the algorithms used to train DL models are not stable themselves. We introduce a new class of algorithms that are stable and prove that they can compute stable neural networks with great accuracy. This is a major step toward the development of a theory of stability for neural networks.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a unique opportunity to reflect on the role of science in society. This paper discusses a classic psychological experiment that has been cited as a case study of how people’s inability to understand exponential growth is the main cause of the pandemic. The experiment’s critical design flaws were overlooked at the time, and the study has become a canonical example of how people fail to understand exponential growth. We discuss the implications of this unique case study for science and society.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and the cause of the disease has been debated for even longer. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a patient from Mexico with a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon, and compared it with that of the causative agent of leprosy, Mycobacterium leprae. We found that the two organisms are remarkably conserved, and that they are still able to cause similar diseases. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of the leprosy pathogen and the evolution of the disease itself. (PsycINFO Database Record

The dynamics of quantum systems is a fundamental ingredient of the physical world. It is therefore of utmost importance to understand how the system’s properties change during the time evolution. In this work, we focus on the entanglement dynamics, which is a key concept in quantum information theory and statistical mechanics. We show that the entanglement dynamics can be understood in terms of the quasiparticles of the system, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This result is a major step forward in the study of the entanglement dynamics, which is a key ingredient in the understanding of the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated quantum systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 500,000 people in the United States and more than 5.5 million people worldwide. The development of a vaccine is the only way to end this pandemic. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is currently in clinical development.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) was characterized by recurrent epidemics and high mortality. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that of rodent transmission. However, the role of human ectoparasite vectors, such as fleas or lice, has been overlooked. Here, we present a mathematical model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides a new perspective on the history of plague and its vectors. It also has implications for the spread of infectious diseases in the present day.

The evolution of the brain is one of the most important and intriguing aspects of animal biology. It is also one of the most difficult to study because of the large size of the organ and the complexity of its function. Here we use the largest dataset of its kind to reconstruct the evolution of the brain by directly analyzing the number of neurons. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been the subject of intense investigation. However, the current understanding of TRAP1 function is limited. We have shown that TRAP1 is required for the maintenance of mitochondrial function and for the regulation of the metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis. These findings provide a mechanistic basis for the role of TRAP1 in cancer and suggest that TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. However, the mechanism by which it does so is not known. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF binds to filaments in a mechanical-dependent manner, and that the binding is enhanced by a mechanical torque. This torque is generated by the mechanical constraint imposed by filament cross-linking. We propose that this mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for our understanding of ADF’s role in severing the actin cortex, which is important for the formation of lamellipodia and filopodia. They also have implications for our understanding of the role of ADF in cancer.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation of reward-related regions and greater desire for food and food-related behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a stronger appetite suppressant than glucose. The results also suggest that the effects of fructose on brain and behavior may be mediated, at least in part, by the hormone insulin. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and for the development of strategies to reduce the consumption of fructose.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian language family is spoken, and it is the only place where the Bantu language family is spoken. We provide a comprehensive view of the human history of Madagascar, which is crucial to understand the origin and the spread of the languages and the culture.

We show that people’s emotions can be transferred to others via social networks. This is a major finding because it suggests that people are not just influenced by the emotions of others, but that they can also influence the emotions of others. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work has implications for the design of social networks, the spread of emotions, and the design of interventions to reduce the spread of negative emotions.

Messenger RNA sequences are modified in a variety of ways, but the impact of these modifications on protein synthesis has not been systematically explored. Here, we show that the presence of a single pseudouridine (Ψ) in an mRNA codon can impede the translation of the mRNA in a reconstituted translation system and in human cells. We also show that the presence of Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence, and that the majority of Ψ moieties in mRNAs are found in coding regions. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in mRNA sequences can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. These findings have implications for understanding the role of mRNA modifications in the regulation of protein synthesis. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and well-being, and is associated with positive changes in these outcomes over time. This study also shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and well-being, and is associated with positive changes in these outcomes over time. This study provides evidence that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a key feature of the history of life in the water. We show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the aquatic environment and is constrained by the energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is one of the most common and widespread diseases in the world, and rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been studied in cell culture, but the mechanisms underlying the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication have not been fully elucidated. Here, we show that mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature. This temperature-dependent growth phenotype is dependent on the MAVS protein, which is a key signaling adaptor of the RIG-I–like receptors (RLRs).

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in their surroundings. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface adhesin type IV pili to sense the mechanical activity of its environment. This mechanochemical sensing system is important for the regulation of surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the quality of global surface water is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and show that the quality of global surface water is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The persistence of SARS-CoV-2 in animals is a major concern, as it could lead to the emergence of new variants that are more transmissible and/or resistant to vaccines and therapeutics. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, which are the predominant cervid in North America. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and highlight the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the history of the development of hydropower and the proliferation of large dams in the developing world. It also examines the challenges of climate change and the need to incorporate it into the consideration of whether to build a dam. The paper also examines the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, the paper proposes innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation of the disease is still controversial. Here, we show that soluble and oligomeric Aβ are the most toxic amyloid species within the brain, and that they are responsible for the activation of neurons, which are the primary source of the proinflammatory factors. Thus, we propose that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain is the primary cause of the neuroinflammation, which is the key event in the AD pathogenesis.

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is of great importance for the study of the development of animal husbandry in general and for the study of the history of the chicken in particular. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced.

The folding of proteins is a key process in biology, and it is of great interest to understand the details of the process. This study describes the folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein, in high structural detail. The results indicate that the folding of the protein is a multistep process, and that the intermediate in the folding process is an obligatory step in the folding pathway. The results are important for understanding the folding of proteins in general.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they are thought to function as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps. Here, we show that, in the presence of stress, the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to decapsulate Np4-capped RNAs, also removes the cap of the predominant decapping substrate, the triphosphorylated RNA. This is the first demonstration of a decapping enzyme that can recognize capped 5′ termini in a manner distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini. The unique manner in which capped substrates bind to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This study highlights the importance of the context in which decapping enzymes operate and the impact that can have on the rates at which specific 5′ termini are deprotected.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. The development of sepsis is associated with a decrease in the number of lymphocytes, which is associated with a poor prognosis. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore lymphocyte function and decrease immunosuppression in sepsis. We demonstrated that citrulline administration was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study is of interest to the scientific community and the general public because it provides evidence for the development of a new therapeutic strategy for sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is the sum of the masses of all the organisms that inhabit the planet. It is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. They also provide a baseline for future studies on the impact of human activities on the global biomass of prominent taxa.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is widely used in electronics, optics, and photonics. However, it is brittle and has a low fracture strain. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, and that its electronic bandgap can be completely closed. We also show that diamond can be used as a mechanical switch. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

The study of plant defense mechanisms has been a major focus of research for decades. However, the molecular mechanisms of plant defense are still poorly understood. Here, we report the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide, which is a member of a large family of nodule-specific peptides, and its mode of action against plant fungal pathogens.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and demonstrate that the female reproductive tract is a source of proteins that support sperm viability. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and demonstrates that the female reproductive tract is a source of proteins that support sperm viability. This work expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions and provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular mechanisms that underlie these interactions. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the surface of platelets. The binding of VWF to GPIbα is important for the formation of platelet aggregates, which are important for hemostasis. We show that force can be used to switch the conformation of VWF, which is important for the function of VWF. This is important for understanding the function of VWF in health and disease.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the role of viruses in the human body has been difficult to study, because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of viruses, which can be used to study the role of viruses in health and disease. The database is available for download and can be used to study the role of viruses in a wide range of diseases. The study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of viruses in the human body.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI processes, such as the influence of aerosols on water cloud droplet formation. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of dual-FOV HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important for the survival of life on the planet. The temperature of the surface of the Earth has been estimated to be 70 ± 15 °C in the Archean, a period of time that is very old.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. They are also the main targets of drugs. The opening and closing of ion channels are controlled by two gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow inactivation/recovery. The two gates are spatially separated in most channels, but the K+ channel BK lacks an intracellular activation gate and shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the relationship between the two gates and the regulation of ion flow in ion channels. (Show more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with an estimated 207 million cases and 435,000 deaths in 2019. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate entry into the human body, but the mechanism of invasion is poorly understood. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the physical properties of the host cell, increasing the tension of the cytoskeleton and reducing the bending rigidity of the membrane, which leads to an increase in invasion efficiency. This study provides a new perspective on the invasion process and opens up new avenues for the development of new antimalarial drugs. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is widely used in electronics, optics, and photonics. However, it is brittle and has a low fracture strain. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, and that its electronic bandgap can be completely closed. We also show that diamond can be used as a mechanical switch. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

The impact of ambient humidity on the severity of influenza virus infection is controversial. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity increases the severity of influenza virus infection. We demonstrate that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair, and that these events are required for the increased disease severity. We also show that low humidity reduces the expression of IFN-stimulated genes in the lung, which is associated with reduced antiviral defense. These results indicate that low humidity impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the role of ambient humidity in the severity of influenza virus infection. They also suggest that humidity may be a potential target for the development of antiviral strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. However, whether and how the brain does so remains unknown. Here, we show that the activity of multiple brain areas increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This pattern of activity suggests that the brain applies a merge operation to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based on sequential transition probabilities, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This model of language processing may be important for understanding the development of language and for the design of language-based therapies.

The Wnt signaling pathway is one of the most important pathways in development. It is also involved in the development of cancer. The pathway is activated by a variety of mechanisms, and the pathway is often activated in cancer. The pathway is also activated in the brain, and in some cases, this activation is important for the development of the brain.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that controls feeding. Here we show that stimulation of LH neurons that release GABA causes rapid vigorous eating in sated mice. We also show that this effect is blocked by lesions of dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and the substantia nigra, suggesting that dopamine is involved in the regulation of feeding. We further show that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of neurons in the LH and in the peri-locus coeruleus region of the hypothalamus. Finally, we show that this system is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. The ability of plants to fix nitrogen (N2) from the atmosphere is a key process in the functioning of the biosphere. However, the amount of fixed N2 is limited by the capacity of the atmosphere to fix N2, and thus, the potential for N2-fixing symbiosis is limited. Here, we report the development of a synthetic plant-controlled N2-fixing symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work is expected to have a significant impact on the field of agriculture and the environment. (Show more)

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

The spider is a model organism for studying the evolution of animal senses, including hearing. However, the hearing of spiders has been studied only in a few species, and the mechanisms of hearing in spiders have not been elucidated. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is able to hear through the web that it manufactures. The web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna, and the spider is able to localize the source of an incoming acoustic wave by sensing the motion of the web. This study provides insights into the evolution of hearing in spiders and the outsourcing of hearing to the web. It also provides a unique model for studying the sensing of the web, the supersizing of sensing, and the regeneration of sensing. The spider is able to functionally adjust and regularly regenerate its external "eardrum" according to its needs.

The health and climate impacts of air pollution and greenhouse gases are intertwined. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil fuels is needed to save millions of lives, restore rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has killed over 500,000 people in the United States alone. The development of vaccines is a critical step in controlling the pandemic. We report the design and development of a subunit vaccine candidate that can be produced at large scale and is expected to be affordable.

The role of ALK in the development of the nervous system has been studied in mice, but the results are controversial. Here, we show that the small secreted ALKAL proteins are able to activate ALK in vitro and in vivo. We also show that the three zebrafish ALKALs are able to induce iridophore development in the absence of Ltk. These results provide evidence that ALKALs are involved in the development of the nervous system and suggest that they may also be involved in the development of the brain in mammals.

The emergence of Yersinia pestis, the pathogen responsible for the Black Death, is one of the most dramatic events in human history. However, the time of its origin and the nature of its early evolution are still debated. Here, we present a large dataset of Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic to the Bronze Age, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during its formative years. Our results suggest that the pathogen was not a single, local lineage but rather a panmictic population that spread across Eurasia. This is in contrast to other pathogens for which ancient genomes are available, which show a clear pattern of parallel diversification. This study provides a new perspective on the early evolution of plague and its relationship to its host. (Less)

This work examined the role of the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support.
