The agricultural management of grasslands and croplands has been shown to affect the quantity and distribution of soil organic carbon (SOC) in the United States and worldwide. However, the extent to which these practices can mitigate the loss of SOC from agricultural soils remains highly uncertain. We show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage and the distribution of SOC between particulate and mineral-associated pools in the United States. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon in the United States and worldwide. Our findings have implications for the design of climate-smart agricultural practices and the development of agricultural policies to mitigate climate change.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses from wildlife to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over to humans. We used this framework to identify the greatest risks and to prioritize research and surveillance efforts. The resulting database, SpillOver, is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. SpillOver is a valuable resource for researchers, policy makers, and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinators to find flowers, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We demonstrate that this alkaloid is attractive to the vertebrate-pollinator Phelsuma geckos, and that the same mechanism is likely to underlie the evolution of this trait in two other species of hummingbird-visited plants. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a highly effective cue for pollinators, and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides a better understanding of the evolution of floral color and the role of nectar in plant reproduction. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period (5th–7th centuries AD) is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 480 and 650 AD. Our data indicate that the genetic ancestry of the individuals in our sample is mostly of northern and central European origin, but that women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. This study provides a unique opportunity to study the genetic history of Europe during a period of major cultural change.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. Our results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. Our findings are important for the development of strategies to prevent and control future zoonotic outbreaks. (Show more)

The ability to rapidly identify the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness is critical to the early detection and response to emerging and reemerging pathogens. We show that metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) can be used to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens in a resource-scarce setting. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of mNGS in resource-scarce settings and the potential for large-scale pathogen surveillance. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response.

The human genome is replicated in a highly coordinated and accurate manner. However, the mechanisms that ensure the faithful replication of the lagging strand template are not fully understood. Here, we report the development of unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that the human pol δ holoenzyme is more stable than its S. cerevisiae counterpart and that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. These results provide a unique platform for studying the dynamics of the human pol δ holoenzyme and its role in lagging strand synthesis. They also provide a foundation for the development of new strategies for the treatment of cancer.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enigmatic problems in science. In this paper, we describe the development of a system that can replicate and amplify genetic information in the absence of proteins. This system is based on an RNA polymerase ribozyme that has been improved by in vitro evolution. The improved polymerase can replicate RNA from an RNA template, amplify RNA by more than 10,000-fold, and synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules. Thus, the system described in this paper provides a means to study the origin of life in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The treatment of COVID-19 is still in the stage of exploration. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can improve the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess is toxic to cells. The role of the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus is to bind copper and impact cellular copper content. This study demonstrates that xanthocillin is a copper-binding molecule and that the xan BGC is expressed in response to copper limitation. The copper-binding properties of xanthocillin and other isocyanide products of the xan BGC have significant implications for the role of these molecules in the regulation of copper homeostasis and in the modulation of interactions with competing microbes.

The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit on Mars is significant because it is a high-temperature (>870 °C) <i>metamorphic</i> phase that is not stable at the present-day surface temperature of <i>∼23 °C</i>. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit on Mars is significant because it is a high-temperature (>870 °C) <i>metamorphic</i> phase that is not stable at the present-day surface temperature of <i>∼23 °C</i>.

Frost events are a major threat to agriculture, forestry, and animal husbandry, but the geographic distribution of frost risk is poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is strongly linked to the evolutionary history of the species involved. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk and to minimize the economic impact of frost events.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of these cells in the pathogenesis of the disease is unclear. Here we show that the development of colitis requires the transition of a subset of Th17 cells to Th1-like cells and that this process requires the activation of Stat4. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of the inflammatory response in inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, the cells that control voluntary muscle movement. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding proteins that are essential for motor neuron function. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, enabling disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening. This method will accelerate the development of new therapies for ALS.

The gut microbiota of arthropods is an important factor in the health and fitness of the vector, and thus, the pathogen. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the microbiota of the vector tick, Ixodes scapularis, to more efficiently colonize the tick. We demonstrate that the pathogen induces the tick to produce an antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the tick gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix. These data provide a mechanistic understanding of how a pathogen can influence the microbiota of its vector to enhance colonization. This knowledge will be important for the development of strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The study of the evolution of the avian tail is critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian body plan. However, the study of the evolution of the avian tail is complicated by the fact that the tail is a complex structure that is difficult to study in fossils.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of the atmosphere. In this paper, we show that the atmosphere plays an important role in the evolution of our climate.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, which are often used to blend in with their environment. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green colors in vertebrates has evolved multiple times, and that the underlying mechanism is the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin, a molecule that is formed when iron is released from hemoglobin. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The development of breast cancer is associated with a loss of the ability to form a blood clot, which is a characteristic of cancer stem cells (CSCs). CSCs are responsible for the initiation and maintenance of the tumor, and are resistant to chemotherapy. We show that hypoxia induces the expression of a demethylase of mRNA, AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which increases the number of breast cancer stem cells. This study provides a mechanism for the role of hypoxia in the development of breast cancer stem cells, and may lead to the development of new therapies for breast cancer.

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical to understanding the causes and consequences of the extinction and recovery. The age model presented here is based on the age of the Permian-Triassic boundary, and the age of the extinction is constrained by the age of the boundary.

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the external environment. It is also the main site of immune surveillance and the first line of defense against invading pathogens. However, the intestinal epithelium is also the main target of many inflammatory diseases, such as inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). IBD is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the overactivation of the immune system. The current treatment of IBD is mainly based on suppressing the immune system, which is not only associated with severe side effects but also fails to achieve the desired therapeutic effect. Therefore, it is of great importance to find a new therapeutic strategy for IBD. Here, we demonstrate that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays a crucial role in the regulation of intestinal homeostasis and that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3)-mediated attenuation of nuclear factor κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides a new therapeutic strategy for IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 in complex with the human ACE2 receptor. We show that the spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is able to bind to the human ACE2 receptor, and that the D614G mutation in the spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is associated with a more open conformation of the spike glycoprotein. These results will be useful for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a decline in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y.

The chemical properties of matter are the basis of chemistry, and the study of chemical properties is the foundation of chemistry. The chemical properties of matter are the result of the interaction of matter with the electromagnetic field, and the study of chemical properties is the foundation of physics.

Fire is a key ecosystem process, but its role in climate change is uncertain. We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the dominant driver of changes in fire activity over the last century. This has led to a reduction in fire activity, which has warmed the climate. However, recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may reverse this, enhancing land carbon uptake and corresponding to offsetting ∼5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. This potentially reduces warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. We show that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our study highlights that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems.

The provision of nutrients to microbial communities associated with epithelial surfaces is a widespread strategy used by animals to regulate their health. However, the mechanisms by which this occurs are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the activities of a symbiotic bacterium in a specific host organ. This glycan is released by host cells in the hours before dusk, when the host is most active. We propose that this strategy is used by hosts to regulate the activities of their symbiotic communities, and that it may be a general mechanism used by animals to control the activities of their microbial communities. This study also provides a model for the study of the regulation of the activities of symbiotic microbial communities. (Show more)

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We show that the method can be applied to a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. We demonstrate that the method can be used to identify latent patterns in text data and to identify gender biases in the latent patterns. The method can be applied to many domains and is flexible enough to be applied to a wide range of text data. The method can also be extended to other domains of interest. The method can be applied to other domains of interest.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe.

Asteroids are a common component of the Northeast Pacific ecosystem. In recent years, a disease has caused the mass mortality of at least 20 species of asteroids. The disease is characterized by rapid degradation of the tissue and is associated with a virus. We show that the virus is the most likely cause of the disease and that the virus has been present in the ecosystem for at least 72 y. The findings have implications for the management of this important ecosystem.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a highly heterogeneous disease, and the development of new and more efficient therapies is urgently needed. Here we show that a monoclonal antibody targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor is able to target and kill AML cells in xenograft models. We demonstrate that this antibody is effective in both mice and humanized mice and that it is able to target both leukemia cells and normal hematopoietic stem cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian language family is spoken, and it is the only place where the Bantu language family is spoken. We provide a comprehensive view of the human history of Madagascar, which is crucial to understand the origin and the spread of the languages and the culture.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA.

The development of new antiviral and vaccine strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic is urgently needed. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to enhance the neutralizing activity of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that can improve the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can potentially contribute to the development of new antiviral and vaccine strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

Crop experts are the backbone of the agricultural sector, and their knowledge is critical to monitor and predict crop conditions. However, the lack of a standardized and systematic way to collect and analyze their data has hindered the development of more accurate and timely crop monitoring systems. We propose a method to convert the original qualitative data from the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey into a continuous, probabilistic variable that can be used to monitor crop conditions and predict crop yields. We show that the CPC reflects the subjective perception of many surveyors at different locations, but the underlying models that describe the reported crop status are statistically robust and maintain similar characteristics across different crops, exhibit long-term stability, and have nation-wide validity. We discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop conditions and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our findings have implications for the development of more accurate and timely crop monitoring systems that can be used to support agricultural decision-making.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be based on the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rate of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and is suitable for the binding of linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The response of soil respiration to climate warming is a key uncertainty in our understanding of the global carbon cycle. This study provides a synthesis of the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key component of the evolution of life on Earth. It is a unique genomic record of the history of life on Earth, and it is a valuable source of information for the study of the origin and evolution of life. The study of the evolution of the plastid genome is hindered by the lack of a complete sequence of the genomes of all living organisms. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of the evolution of the plastid genome during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on the plastid genome in a stepwise manner. Our findings are important for the understanding of the evolution of the plastid genome and the origin of life. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was the result of a combination of natural and anthropogenic factors. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the drought by a factor of five to six. This study highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also provide a valuable case study for the use of high-resolution climate models in the study of drought risk in SSA.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major scientific event of the 20th century. The first naturally occurring quasicrystal was discovered in the Khatyrka meteorite in 1969. Since then, many more have been found, but the discovery of a naturally occurring quasicrystal that is not a product of meteorite impact has been elusive. Here, we report the discovery of a naturally occurring icosahedral quasicrystal in red trinitite, the material that resulted from the first nuclear test explosion.

(Bacterio)chlorophyll biosynthesis is one of the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the pathway, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes using different chemistries. Here we show that the two enzymes are members of a family of enzymes that catalyze the formation of the isocyclic fifth ring in a variety of biological pathways.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of neurodegenerative diseases, and neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase, ASK1, which is known to be involved in the regulation of cell survival and death. In this study, we found that ASK1 is involved in the regulation of neuroinflammation in the central nervous system. We also found that ASK1 is involved in the generation of a proinflammatory environment in microglia, which subsequently activates astrocytes to exacerbate neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a better understanding of the role of ASK1 in neuroinflammation and autoimmune diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought has increased in California over the past century, and that the probability of drought has increased in recent decades. In addition, the probability that precipitation deficits are also warm has increased. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex disorder with a variety of symptoms, and the etiology is still unknown. We used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our findings provide a new approach to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. This approach may be useful for the identification of the causal genes and the elucidation of the mechanisms of autism. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work offers the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also serves to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling, but its physiological role has remained elusive. Here, we show that loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 and gain-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel regulator STIM1 result in a spectrum of phenotypes, including hematological abnormalities, that are reminiscent of Stormorken syndrome. These data expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (PsycINFO Database Record

The spread of protein aggregates in the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a model of Huntington’s disease to demonstrate that protein aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons, and we show that the release of aggregates requires active fusion of vesicles with the cell body. These results provide a model for the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and suggest that targeting the release of aggregates may be a potential therapeutic strategy. (PsycINFO Database Record

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are still poorly understood. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system and the potential for MTX as a therapeutic target for the treatment of viral infections. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and thus requires the one-carbon units provided by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that this enzyme is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer. We also show that cancer cells have unique metabolic vulnerabilities, and that these can be exploited to develop more effective cancer therapies.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies that are present in all forms of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This is a significant finding that may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for ALS. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The study of the evolution of the angiosperms has been hampered by the lack of a good understanding of the earliest members of this group. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, opens the possibility that aquatic plants were common at an early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The evolution of viruses is of fundamental importance for understanding the origin and evolution of life. Here we present the first ancient viral sequences, which show that the human pathogen B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. We also show that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought, which is important for understanding the evolution of viruses in general.

Sea level is a sensitive indicator of climate change because it rises and falls when the weight of the atmosphere and the water column fall and rise, pressuring and draining the world’s oceans. We find that the rate of sea level rise has been accelerating over the last 25 y, driven by both ocean warming and melting of the Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets. Our results provide a more precise estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is important for understanding the magnitude of past and future sea level rise and for evaluating the performance of climate models.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, pain has increased with age for each successive birth cohort, and that this increase is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. Thus, the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950 is not limited to the decline in manufacturing jobs, but extends to the erosion of working-class health.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. Here, we describe the application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. This integrated approach is able to provide atomic-resolution characterization of the active site, including the protonation states of the cofactor, substrate, and catalytic side chains, as well as the location and orientation of crystallographic waters within the active site. This detailed picture of structure and reactivity emerges, highlighting the fate of the L-serine hydroxyl leaving group and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This work provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional structure of the active site, which is key to understanding why the natural substrate indole reacts, while benzimidazole does not. This work also demonstrates the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into the reaction pathways of enzymes. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus that has caused a number of human outbreaks. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease emphasizes the need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug that is already in clinical use, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This suggests that remdesivir may be a useful treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses.

The provision of nutrients to microbial communities associated with epithelial surfaces is a widespread strategy used by animals to regulate their health. However, the mechanisms by which this occurs are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the activities of a symbiotic bacterium in a specific host organ. This glycan is released by host cells in the hours before dusk, when the host is most active. We propose that this strategy is used by hosts to control the activities of their symbiotic communities, and that it may be a general mechanism used by animals to control the activities of their microbial communities. This study also provides a model for the study of the dynamics of the interactions between animals and their microbial communities. (Show more)

This study has implications for the field of education, as well as for the fields of psychology and social work. It shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention, and that this change can have a positive impact on the quality of teacher–student relationships and student behavior. It also shows that students’ perspectives can be valued in the classroom, and that this can have a positive impact on the quality of teacher–student relationships and student behavior. Finally, it shows that students’ perspectives can be valued in the classroom, and that this can have a positive impact on the quality of teacher–student relationships and student behavior.

DNA alkylation is one of the most common DNA lesions, which can lead to a variety of diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. Here, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcriptional fidelity of RNA polymerase II. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions can induce distinct transcriptional stalling profiles, which are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop), which is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. This work will be helpful for the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of cancer and other diseases caused by DNA alkylation.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe pneumonia. To better understand the role of the spike (S) glycoproteins in MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the sequential cleavage of the S proteins. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. (PsycINFO Database Record

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. The food choices of the world’s richest people have a disproportionate impact on the environment, and the food choices of the world’s richest people are largely determined by the food choices of the world’s richest people. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a university cafeteria can increase sales of vegetarian meals by 40%. This is a significant contribution to the fight against climate change.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. Here we apply quantitative proteomics to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a rapid understanding of the molecular basis of the disease and the virus. Here, we report the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein, which is proposed to be involved in immune evasion. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for the virus to evade the immune system. This structure will be important for understanding the role of ORF8 in the disease and for the development of antiviral strategies.

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a model for studying the mechanisms of cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypoxia are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats, and that this is associated with an increase in the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4), endothelin-1 (ET-1), and corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) in the cortex. We also show that the increase in AQP4 expression is associated with an increase in the expression of endothelin-converting enzyme (ECE), which is a key enzyme in the conversion of ET-1 to endothelin-2 (ET-2). Finally, we show that the increase in AQP4 expression is blocked by an ECE inhibitor. These results suggest that hypoxia induces cerebral edema by increasing the expression of AQP4, which in turn leads to an increase in the expression of ECE, and the conversion of ET-1 to ET-2, which in turn contributes to the increase in AQP4 expression. This study provides a new understanding of the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypoxia. (Show more)

We live in an era of big data and complex statistical modeling. The challenge is to make inferences from these data that are both accurate and efficient. We describe a new approach to this challenge that is based on selective inference. This approach is based on the idea that we should set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see. We illustrate the approach using forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We believe that this approach will be of interest to statisticians, data miners, and others who are interested in making accurate and efficient inferences from big data.

The development of vascular networks is a key process for the regeneration of organs. In this study, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the formation of vascular networks in the liver. This study provides a new approach for the development of vascular networks in the liver and other organs.

The identification of “orphan” receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) with oncogenic potential has led to the development of a number of targeted therapies. Here, we show that the zebrafish genome contains three genes encoding ligands for the oncogenic RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). We demonstrate that these ligands play an important role in the development of the zebrafish eye and the patterning of the adult body color. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a foundation for the development of targeted therapies for cancer and other diseases. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cell remains unknown. Herein, using global and β-cell–specific knockout mouse models, we revealed a distinct role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis through peripheral tissues and β-cells. Specially, although STING beneficially alleviated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance induced by high-fat diet, it surprisingly impaired islet glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS). Importantly, STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis suggested that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide a new perspective for the development of therapeutic strategies for

Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus using in vitro experiments. Using silent trans-complementary mutants, we then demonstrated that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction did not affect the HA titer of the mutant viruses, suggesting that the same amount of viral particles was produced. However, it nonspecifically decreased the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. Competition experiments indicated that this interaction favored copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. The interaction we identified involves regions not previously designated as packaging signals and is not widely conserved among influenza A virus. Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is associated with the development of atherosclerotic lesions. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of factors. In this study, we found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by disturbed flow is a critical factor in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerosis. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, the role of people in increasing the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire is largely unknown. We show that human-caused wildfires have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States. This expansion has been driven by an increase in the number of wildfires, rather than an increase in the number of lightning-caused wildfires. Actions to reduce the number of wildfires started by humans should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control, but their direct molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease and the factors that determine the severity of the disease are not well understood. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the growth and clearance of ZIKV within an individual are important factors that determine the severity of the disease. We also show that the timing of treatment is important and that antiviral drugs can be effective in reducing the severity of the disease. Our results provide insights into the factors that determine the severity of the disease and the factors that determine the efficacy of antiviral drugs. These results are important for the development of effective strategies to control the spread of ZIKV. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most diverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are threatened by a variety of human activities and climate change. One of the most severe threats is the breakdown of the symbiotic relationship between corals and their algae, which is the result of a combination of environmental and genetic factors. Here, we show that the breakdown of the symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress, which is a key factor in the early stages of bleaching. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general.

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the environment. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn, trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome and restore the barrier function of the epithelium. Our results identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in the development of intestinal tumors and for developing strategies to restore the barrier function of the intestinal epithelium in the context of cancer.

Chemotherapy is an important treatment for breast cancer, but the response of individual patients to chemotherapy varies widely. We show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade, form spheroids, engraft in mice, and survive treatment with paclitaxel. Furthermore, we show that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can reduce the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduce activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impair the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record

The timing of the onset of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is a key piece of the climate puzzle, but the cause of this event is still debated. Here we show that a series of volcanic eruptions, which occurred exactly at the time of the onset of deglaciation, are likely to have caused the climate changes.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but are often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which is the first of its kind. We find that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis reveals that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, but that these populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our data can be used to identify regions where fisheries are most likely to provide food security and biodiversity conservation, and to prioritize the development of more sustainable fisheries.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the proposed material are responsible for the high capacity and the safe operation of the full cell. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new perspective for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This work is expected to be a milestone in the field of energy storage.

The ability to regenerate is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery provides a unique platform for the discovery of novel genes involved in the control of regeneration in the adult nervous system.

The process of meiosis is essential for the production of genetically diverse gametes, and the rate of recombination is a key parameter that determines the rate of genetic change. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a wild plant, and we show that the pattern of recombination is similar to that in yeast and in mice. These results provide a foundation for understanding the evolution of recombination in plants and for the development of new models for the study of meiosis in flowering plants.

The resting state network (RSN) model has been widely used to describe the organization of the human brain. However, the RSN model is based on the analysis of fluctuations in functional MRI signal, representing a small fraction of total neuronal activity. Here, we show that the dominant metabolic RSN in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease (PD), this RSN is subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. Significant reductions in the default mode network were already present in Alzheimer’s disease, progressing over time. Metabolic imaging can directly provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA that regulates translation. We show that a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group, is also found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. This 5′ NAD+ cap is found on pre-mRNAs and, in the case of mitochondrial transcripts, is not 5′ end processed. This discovery of a second 5′ modification raises the possibility that the 5′ NAD+ cap could regulate translation of specific classes of mRNA.

The study of epigenetic changes in diabetes is of great interest because of the potential role of DNA methylation in the development of diabetes complications. We show that DNA methylation of specific loci in whole blood and monocytes from people with diabetes is altered during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT), a landmark study in the field of diabetes, and that these changes are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and is characterized by poor prognosis. Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of TNBC tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Psyc

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease that affects the brain and the gut. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The production of volatile compounds is a key feature of fruit ripening, and the tomato is a model system for studying this process. However, the biosynthetic pathways of many of these compounds are not known. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of a wide range of nitrogenous volatile compounds in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce these compounds. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biochemistry of fruit ripening and the development of new flavor profiles in fruit. (Show more)

The loss of biodiversity and the warming of the planet are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of the Earth’s ecosystems. Here we show that the impacts of these two threats are not independent of each other. We demonstrate that the impacts of warming on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are dependent on the thermal tolerance of species. Our results highlight that the loss of biodiversity will exacerbate the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning, and that the impacts of warming on biodiversity will be exacerbated by the loss of biodiversity.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation, and its neurons are thought to form a map of the local environment. However, the organization of these neurons is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be the main neurons for forming the map of the local environment, are strongly coupled among themselves but weakly coupled to other cell types. These results suggest that grid cells might form a network that is distinct from that of other neurons. This study provides a new approach to understanding the organization of neurons in the MEC.
