Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for flowering of the host plant, but not for flowering of the parasitic dodder. This study illustrates that flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes, and that the flowering signal FT is required for flowering of the host plant, but not for flowering of the parasitic dodder.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized form of nigral innervation that is likely to be important to the function of this system. We show that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We are often asked, “Do you and [person you’re interested in] click?” We show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.” This signal is used by people to gauge whether they are connected to others, and by others to gauge whether two people are connected to each other.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN automaticity is regulated by specialized cardiomyocytes, which are known as SAN cells (SANCs). However, the molecular mechanisms that govern SAN function are not fully understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in SANCs and is required for the maintenance of SAN automaticity. Our studies reveal that STIM1 regulates SAN function by linking the content of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores with the electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane of SANCs. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms that govern SAN function and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of heart failure. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense has been debated. Here, we show that Si accumulation in rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, by priming the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si priming of JA signaling may be a general mechanism for plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based pest management strategies. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of the lipidome in murine macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be based on the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rate of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and is able to bind information over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical area of research due to the importance of plant-based biomolecules in agriculture and the pharmaceutical industry. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants with DNA nanostructures and the impact of the DNA nanostructure geometry on the delivery and gene silencing efficiency. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are critical design parameters for the delivery and gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and the impact of the geometry of the DNA nanostructure on the delivery and gene silencing efficiency. This work will be of interest to the plant biology and synthetic biology communities. (Show more)

The world’s largest freshwater bodies are often viewed as isolated systems, but they are connected to the coastal zone by a network of tributaries. We show that the coastal zone of Lake Michigan is dominated by a small number of large tributaries, but that the vast majority of the daily nutrient loads that fuel algal blooms in the nearshore zone come from small tributaries. Our findings suggest that the coastal zone of large lakes may be more vulnerable to nutrient loading from small tributaries than previously thought.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “optimal fluctuation” phenomenon in physics, which has been observed in a variety of systems. We discuss the implications of our results for the study of complex systems in general and for the design of catalytic systems in particular.

This study offers a mechanistic understanding of the effects of a specific type of autoimmune encephalitis on the brain’s electrical activity. This knowledge may help in the development of new treatments for this disease.

The history of carbon (C) perturbations throughout Earth’s history has provided key insights into the response of the Earth system to abrupt warming. However, most studies focused on short-term warming events superimposed on longer-term greenhouse climate states. Here, we present an integrated proxy (carbon and uranium [U] isotopes and paleo CO2) and multicomponent modeling approach to investigate an abrupt C perturbation and global warming event (∼304 Ma) that occurred during a paleo-glacial state. We report pronounced negative C and U isotopic excursions coincident with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 partial pressure and a biodiversity nadir. The isotopic excursions can be linked to an injection of organic matter–derived C over ∼300 kyr and to near 20% of areal extent of seafloor anoxia. Earth system modeling indicates that widespread anoxic conditions can be linked to enhanced thermocline stratification and increased nutrient fluxes during this global warming within an icehouse. This study highlights the importance of the timing of the C cycle in the history of the Earth system.

The palm oil industry is a major driver of tropical deforestation, and the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme. We show that RSPO certification is associated with a 33% reduction in deforestation in oil palm plantations, but that certification has no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection. Our results suggest that certification is not yet having a large impact on deforestation, and that certification is not a silver bullet for the palm oil industry.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. The exocyst complex is involved in the regulation of plant growth and development, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

The sex of an individual is determined by the genetic sex of the organism, which is often the result of a cascade of developmental sex differences. In species with polygenic sex determination, multiple alleles are involved in the determination of sex, resulting in a spectrum of sex classes. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where two alleles interact to produce siblings with four possible sex classes. We find that polygenic sex determination can produce modular variation in morphological and behavioral traits, and that the evolution or introgression of a newly acquired sex determiner creates additional axes of phenotypic variation. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. (PsycINFO Database Record

The retina is a unique tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species and photoproducts of vitamin A. We sought to understand the role of iron in the retina and found that iron levels impact the retina in a manner that is distinct from its impact in other tissues. In particular, iron levels promote the photooxidation and photodegradation of the retinal photoreceptor pigment A2E. These findings have implications for the understanding of the role of iron in the retina and for the development of strategies to protect the retina from damage. (PsycINFO Database Record

Predator specialization is a fundamental process in ecology and evolution, but it is often considered a dead end due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, have evolved to be highly specialized on different prey types, and that these shifts are linked to the evolution of their specialized tentacles. Our findings help to understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs, and how this process can be linked to the evolution of morphological innovations.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This study also provides a new fossil record for the evolution of the human hand, which is important for understanding the evolution of the hand in the context of the evolution of the human species.

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and thus requires the one-carbon units provided by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that this enzyme is a targetable metabolic deficiency of colon cancer. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition in colon cancer, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These studies provide a foundation for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a new class of cancer therapeutics.

The role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the need for more research on the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets.

Modern agriculture is a key driver of the global food production system, but it is also a major contributor to the loss of soil productivity. The mechanization of agriculture has increased the capacity of farm machinery, but the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that the increase in subsoil compaction risk is a consequence of the increase in vehicle weight, and that this is a consequence of the increase in vehicle size.
